snippet: Citing GPS data from New York City yellow cabs, the Bloomberg administration said that average traffic speeds south of 60th Street in Manhattan had increased nearly 7 percent since 2008.
abstract: Bloomberg administration, citing GPS data from New York City yellow cabs, reports that average traffic speeds in Manhattan's central business district south of 60th street have increased nearly 7 percent since 2008; Transportation Dept officials say figures prove that traffic flow has at least remained stable after heavily-contested introduction of pedestrian plazas and hundreds of miles of bike lanes.
lead_paragraph: Citing GPS data from New York City yellow cabs, the Bloomberg administration said that average traffic speeds south of 60th Street in Manhattan had increased nearly 7 percent since 2008.

headline.main: In Bloomberg’s City of Bike Lanes, Data Show, Cabs Gain a Little Speed
headline.print_headline: In Bloomberg’s City of Bike Lanes, Data Show, Cabs Gain a Little Speed
